results.title: Robert Rauschenberg: man at work
results.creator_credit: Chris Granlund, Arthaus, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Robert Rauschenberg, one of the most important artists of the twentieth century. life works and practice are featured in this documentary. Influenced mostly by popular culture and the everyday his practice has continued for over 40 years being one of the most influential artists of his time. His retrospective at the Guggenheim, New York in 1997 is featured as well as his 1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece, a multipanelled autobiographical piece begun in 1982 that is expected to out measure the length of its title once completed. Living and working since the 70’s in his Captiva island studio off Florida, Rauschenberg constructs 1/4 Mile, demonstrating his process whilst giving us an opportunity to see the piece for the first time in its entirety. Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.title: Christian Boltanski
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A comprehensive documentary on one of the most important contemporary artists of 20th Century France, Christian Boltanski. Interviewed by Melvyn Bragg, Boltanski’s childhood influences, mostly the affects of the Holocaust on society in post-war France are explored in direct reference to a series of Boltanski’s work spanning over a period of 30 years. Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).

results.title: Miro: theatre of dreams
results.creator_credit: Robin Lough, Christopher Martin, BBC-TV, Poorhouse Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A biographical documentary on Spanish painter and sculptor Joan Miro (1893-1983), renowned for his part in the 1920s surrealist movement in Paris in his exploration of the inner world of dreams and the unconscious in a range of works. The documentary traces his involvement at the age of 85 in putting together a strongly political theatrical piece with young actors under the banner of Claca theatre, a theatre ideally aimed to translate to performance anywhere and as a surreal vision of traditional Catalonian folk culture. The program discusses his fascination with this historical theatrical form from childhood and the seriousness behind the concept of monsters in the Claca production which underlines his opposition to tyrants in Spanish history, a reference to the fascist invasion of Spain in 1936 and Franco’s subsequent leadership. Interwoven with the coverage of the progress of Claca’s production is a very personal study of Miro’s life and work through interviews with Miro himself on the inspirations for his work from childhood to recent history and the underlying philosophy in his work of not distorting life but seeing it with the third eye, that is seeing it as a veil in the world of dreams. The program also explores the contents of his studio in Majorca, his working materials and the items he collected from travel abroad. A meditation on their reference points in his work and artistic process is presented through stills of his work and visuals of him working in his studio and discussing his instinctive style of painting which draws from ordinary life to create a surrealist poetic. Footage of the premiere of Claca Theatre when Catalonia returned to an independent state and a presentation of Miro’s thoughts at the time closes the program and underlines the continued significance and intensity of Miro’s artistic vision of history interwoven with the immediacy of everyday life.

results.title: Andy Warhol
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Andy Warhol was born Andrew Warhola in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1928. Upon graduation from Carnegie Institute of Technology, he moved to New York and began working as a commercial artist where his success in graphic arts and illustration was celebrated. This documentary begins with his early commercial work and follows his career over 20 years until his death in 1987. Contains interviews with cast members from Warhol’s films “Sleep” and “Chelsea Girls”.

results.title: Jackson Pollock
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, RM Arts and South Bank Show
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary shows Jackson Pollack, the most famous twentieth century American painter, as the controversial star of the New York art scene in the forties and fifties, who founded the movement ‘Abstract Expressionism’. It is an interesting look at Pollock’s life and death through various interviews with friends, from the cowboy myth, to the drunken, fast driving masculine artist. It is a documentary as revealing and engaging as Pollock’s work itself. There is footage of the artist at work finding his own technique of dripping and splashing fluid paint onto unstretched canvas layed out on the floor. It traces his history as an artist showing his early influences of native American sandpainting to his rise as an abstract expressionist. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: W. Eugene Smith
results.creator_credit: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WES Foree, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Renowned war photographer W. Eugene Smith (1918-78) photographed the victims of war throughout his distinguished career. This is an insightful portrait of a powerful and sensitive artist who used his photographs to transmit a message against the greed, the stupidity and the intolerance that causes wars that bring cruelty and suffering to humanity.

results.title: Francis Bacon
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, London Weekend Television and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This seminal documentary, edited and narrated by Melvyn Bragg remains one of the ‘stand out’ documentaries that surveys the life, work and motivations of British painter, Francis Bacon, through a series of interviews. Bacon, an extraordinary man, laconically introduces the relationship between broad formalist concerns and attempts to connect with the subconscious. Bacon articulates his response to images of a distressed humanity, revealing his deep fascination with the human body and its connection with much of Bacon’s life philosophies. Gritty in content, Bacon’s paintings reveal much of the ‘violence of life and death’ but seek to describe the normality of this with controlled sense of chaos, ‘capturing the moment’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hinton, London Weekend Television and RM Arts
results.description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This seminal documentary, edited and narrated by Melvyn Bragg remains one of the ‘stand out’ documentaries that surveys the life, work and motivations of British painter, Francis Bacon, through a series of interviews. Bacon, an extraordinary man, laconically introduces the relationship between broad formalist concerns and attempts to connect with the subconscious. Bacon articulates his response to images of a distressed humanity, revealing his deep fascination with the human body and its connection with much of Bacon’s life philosophies. Gritty in content, Bacon’s paintings reveal much of the ‘violence of life and death’ but seek to describe the normality of this with controlled sense of chaos, ‘capturing the moment’.

results.title: Raphael: the prince of painters. [Vol. 2]
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The second of a two volume series, ‘Raphael: the prince of painters’ provides great background to Raphael’s life, influences, education and professional friendships as an artist beyond his apprentice years. The documentary starts with Raphael’s arrival to Rome aged twenty-five. Already famous for his work in Florence this volume focuses on Raphael’s art as a matured vision and reflects on his relationship with the Vatican and Pope Julius the second and his entry into aristocratic high culture at a time of unrivalled confidence and riches in the Catholic Church. Raphael’s tapestry work at the Sistine Chapel and the ‘Transfiguration’ altarpiece are focussed on in this documentary, his philosophy being reflected by his close friendships in humanist thinkers Baldassare Castiglione and Pietro Bembo and architect Donato Bramante. Written and narrated by David Thompson.

results.title: Raphael: the apprentice years. [Vol. 1]
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Part one of a two volume series, ‘Raphael: the apprentice years’ provides great background to Raphael’s life, influences, education and professional friendships as a young man up to the age of 25. In this documentary writer and narrator David Thompson (former critic of The Times) reappraises the work of Raphael providing an in-depth look into the development of his career and his relationships with mentors and leading contemporaries like Pierro Della Francesca, Leonardo di Vinci and Michelangelo. His formative years as an artist are covered from his life as a young apprentice in Urbino influenced by the work of Pierro Della Francesca to Peruggia where he was fellow student with Leonardo da Vinci and Florence where he had formed many of his friendships with notable contemporaries as Michelangelo. Shot on location the documentary discusses liberally the influences upon his work with in-depth coverage of his drawings, paintings and sculptural reliefs. What is revealed is Raphael’s passion for nature, light and colour, classicism, the ‘School of Athens’, mathematics and perspective.
